PRINCE ALBERT, N.W.T.

FRIDAY, AUGUST 8, 1884.

INCORPORATION.

The delay in the part of the Lieutenant-Governor in allowing the incorporation of Prince Albert, has been a cause of considerable disappointment to the inhabitants of that place. The result of the proceedings directed at the proprietors since the opposition was raised will not cause the delay. There can be no excuse for the delay, no matter how much might be said in its favor. In this matter, as in all others, our people, who waited upon His Honor, had the assurance from his own lips that it was by the advice of his legal advisers or of himself that he had delayed so long. We hope this may prove a caution to some of our community to abstain from rushing into conclusions formed on insufficient data, and to give more thought to matters of importance. Everything considered, perhaps this necessary delay may have been ordered for the best; as we will now have an excuse for not rushing into matters which might originally have been made things done in too great a hurry. We have every hope that the present session of the North-West Assembly will see the incorporation of Prince Albert, and that we shall see a situation that will be the talk of the people themselves should we fail speedily to secure municipal organization. There can be no doubt that municipal organization is needed by a very large majority of our community, although unhappily there has been a good deal of difference of opinion with regard to the details, whether as to whether each constituency should be represented by a vote of the whole municipality, or each by separate wards. That the latter plan is from every point of view the fair way seems obvious to anyone who has given the question any attention during the period having elapsed between the last election and the present one. It is evident that the question is being discussed, and that three wards, against one in the extreme west, and one at the extreme east, are ample sufficient for the interests of those between them. The question has been brought up by time and reflection been made apparent to most of those who were once against themselves to the councils of a far-travelled friend, who has visited us abroad, and who has heard of progress and enlightenment, which in his days gone by guided their free-booting Highland ancestors, the law of might being the law of right, or to quote the poet Wordsworth:

For why? Because the good old rule beareth them: the simple plan:
That they should take who have the power,
And keep them who can keep.

And they should keep who can.

If things proceed as favorably as we expect, it is high time for our prospective wardens to begin shaping their respective electoral districts with regard to the policy they intend to impose upon candidates for municipal office unless they propose to postpone their action until such time as they elect others unconditionally and then condemn their course. NORTH WEST COUNCIL.

Tuesday, July 17.

Council met at 2 p.m. His Honor presiding.

The minutes having been read and adopted, Col. McLeod moved the following resolutions:

That in the opinion of the Council, a marked evidence of recognition of the good faith and true allegiance to the Crown of Canada by Mr. Crowfoot and the other chiefs of the Blackfoot nation who appeared in the Council on Tuesday last, and His Honor being led to present them some of His Crowfoot and his associates as a mark of the esteem in which his nation is held, it has been resolved by the Committee to consider the above resolution.

Mr. Oliver objected to the passage of the resolution on the grounds that the money was raised from which the revenue at the disposal of the Council is derived, and the members should not consent to the payment of money for such a purpose.

Resolution concurred in.

ORDINANCES INTRODUCED.

Mr. McLeod introduced an ordinance for the planting of forest trees.

Mr. Macdonald "An Ordinance to establish Municipal Lines."

Mr. Macdonald, Chairman of the Finance Committee, then presented the following report:

Your committee report they have examined statement of receipts and expenditures and find same correct.

They submit that the sum of thirty-five pounds be charged against the fund granted by the Parliament of Canada for expenses of the North West Territories, and recommend in future that all similar expenditures should be charged against the fund granted by the Parliament of Canada for expenses of the North West Territories.

Mr. Oliver moved a resolution that the Minister of the Interior and the Hon. Mr. Macdonald be requested to present the Federal authorities with the amount of the indemnity paid to the Indians due to the Mounted Police.

That the sum of $1,000 voted in session of 1883 for Public Works be used for the erection of buildings to be erected against the local expenditure fund.

Mr. Oliver moved a resolution that the Council might with propriety raise the question as to what the nature of their executive capacity would appear to be, and that the Council do in future exercise its powers in the manner in which the executive authority of the North West Territories is exercised.

Mr. Oliver moved a resolution that the funds granted for the Government of the North West Territories be expended within the province of the North West Territories.

They would also call the attention of the Council to the fact that until the completion of the railway line, the North West Territories will be unable to provide the services of the North West Territories which under the control of the Council do depend upon the services of the North West Territories.

Mr. Oliver moved a resolution that the Council do in future expend its funds for the erection of buildings to be erected against the local expenditure fund.

The House resolved into committee to consider amendments to Ordinance re-creating the town of Fort Macleod.

Amendment introduced providing in effect, that owner shall have lien only for balance due and dispensing with necessity of registration, as originally was proposed.

Col. McLeod moved that the deposits to the new town of Macleod agreeable to the terms of the proposal be made.

The members of the deposits were then introduced and requested to address the Council on the proposed terms.

Mr. James, on behalf of his associates, said he saw no objection to the proposed act, and was of opinion that had the matter been brought before him, he would have been prepared to make the deposits.

Mr. Oliver moved a resolution that the existing act would never have been passed.

Mr. Oliver thanked the Council for the satisfactory manner of the proposed act and for the attention they had given to it during the debate.

Mr. Oliver moved a resolution that the Council be adjourned sine die.

The motion was carried.

The House adjourned at 5 p.m.
